com:
/vrpg/ is a place to discuss all types of role-playing video games, including single-player, multi-player, and massively multi-player, turn-based and real-time action, western-style and JRPG.

Does this mean RPGs are banned on other video game boards? No! /vrpg/ is just a separate board specifically focused on RPGs where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vrpg/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/.

>>2885074
I think it's the best version. The leveling system is now based on individual characters so you can raise them however you want. They still have some stat growth based on the class they level up as but since everyone levels individually they won't miss out on levelling as a job you already levelled. There are stat charms, consumable items, you can use on characters to improve stats further.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2885074
Yeah but it's not flawless. The removal of TP made some classes good and some classes awful. Like Ninja for example, removal of TP means its entire lifeline is on random skills popping up at the beginning of its turn. Other classes like Rune Fencer are really fucking good because of the change and now they can spam finishers.

Otherwise, some quests were retooled to be less grindy, most notably Deneb. Crafting isn't dogshit, but it's pretty much mandatory now. You get all the DLC content that wasn't in the SNES version. It's the least grindy version and you can't powerlevel past enemies because of level caps that go higher after story events. The only grind is if you can't decide on a weapon.

Classes DO have different growths but it's likely not a big deal. Uniques come with such a hard stat bias it's really predetermined. If you're an OCD faggot you can JUST kill the leader in story missions then level up by auto battling in training as the class you want.

I think the problems people are having are mostly with the level scaling. The balance issues in every version of the game are still there too and with the retooled penetration formula archers are fucking useless.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2885196
People moaning about level scaling are braindead retard, even during story mode with fights 2/3 levels above you the game gives you all the tools to win.

I also disagree with Archers being useless, but I understand most people complain about it by comparing them to the busted PSP version. They're not walking nuke launcher anymore but they still have their use especially early game to guarantee status effect. Having a bunch of enemies stunned / charmed / petrified trivialize many of the "hard" boss battles.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2885196
>Rune Fencers
Were always good in PSP but only after Level 25 when you got Summons. They're just competent all game long now.
>Ninjas and Archers
Are still useful but require a bit more thought to use because Penetration thresholds are globally higher due to everyone being able to equip a full set of equipment instead of just two pieces. If you're running into the penetration floor, use +Str gear. Even during the dreaded Baldur Bow+1 era, Arycelle and my Ninja were contributing by spamming guaranteed Silences and Stuns.
>Level scaling
People are just obsessed with the idea of having equal levels as the enemy. You can outgear enemies for most of the game thanks to +1 gear which can offset the minor stat advantages that enemies generally have on you. In PoTD where it actually does get to +10 levels above you in some fights, you can brute force them with magic.
Furthermore, freezing levels actually allows you to carefully curate growths. The non HP/MP stats might not seem like much but it can add up before charm spam endgame.

com:
I've never played a CRPG before and now seems like a good time to get into one.
I was thinking about Pathfinder WOTR or Baldur's Gate. Is there one that's a must-play?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2881219
If you want modern and the widest scope/mod/hours for the money: Pathfinder.
If you have zero tolerance for wokeshit: BG
If you have low tolerance for wokeshit: PKM or DoS2, not Wrath
If you have low tolerance for reddit/joss whedon: Stay away from DoS2 and some of the Wrath companion.
If you want co-op and something other than D&D: DoS2

Pillars has wokeshit all over and is the shortest and the worst of the whole list both mechanically and writing wise and POE2 is obviously unfinished because they didn't finish the boat combat mechanic. It has mostly the worst aspects in every category. The only thing it has over other crpg is slightly more streamlined tweak of archaic D&D mechanics "le balance man" which are a wash because it also removes build permutations and it's real strength: better custom party AI.

DOS2 has the most creative modern mechanics which are better suited to CRPG in some ways, but also locked into turn based and a more shallow game in scope and writing wise overall, but the companion stories are decent and it is the only one with co-op. DOS2 is very reddit in the writing but also the least woke of the modern settings in some ways.

Pathfinder is the most robust system and can be made even more robust with mods. Easily wins if you think about CRPG in terms of hours/dollar but I just give you the facts and you can follow your own priorities.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2885004
It would take an incredible amount of stuff to cause this. What maker are you using, and how many operations are being called per loop of your event? Every time your cursor moves or updates, you should be going through the whole stack of processes in one shot which updates the menu position/variables/any images that go with that. Parallel events should be used sparingly, if at all, and only for stuff that can't be done with individual calls like cursor glow effects or other stuff that has to literally be looping constantly.
The main thing I can think of that would cause menu lag would be loops that don't fully break and stack up in processing. Most of the time this would happen when breaking out of a deeper loop level and going back to a previous menu.
>Main Menu
>>Status
>>>Character Equipment
If you're not careful to make sure you truly break out of the deeper loops, sometimes those will still be in the processing queue even though they're not visibly doing anything.

name: Anonymous
com:
Daggerfall requires a lot of effort on the player to enjoy. A lot of suspension of disbelief. But if you allow yourself to be fooled, it is actually a very fun game. Even though every quest and city is procedurally generated, after you've been playing for a while you kind of allow the illusion that every location is unique to grow on you. You get a sense of scale and realism that no other RPG offers.

I remember Zaric saying that every region in Daggerfall felt unique to him. I thought this was nonsense. How could a region feel unique when it uses the exact same generation algorithm as every other generic region in the game? I didn't understand this until I properly played Daggerfall and gave it a chance rather than dismissing it as procedurally generated garbage like I had done before. For example, over time you remember certain town layouts, you find a city with all the right services that your character requires in the one place, or you grow fond of a city that you've done a lot of quests in. And after a while of helping people out you see your reputation in a region has grown, it feels good that your actions in this world actually mean something.

Daggerfall definitely has something that no other RPG I've played has. A sense of immersion that you really are just an itinerant adventurer living in a fantasy world. Even though it's from 1996 it feels surprisingly modern in the amount of freedom it gives you.

Of course, the Unity version and shit ton of mods help a lot too. There are a lot of quest and world overhaul mods so the game doesn't feel so samey all the time.

sub: What is the correct mindset to enjoy DRPGs?
com:
I've tried playing some DRPGs and there's a lot of things I like about them:
>party management
>free character creation, allowing for a multitude of approaches
>first person exploration is usually immersive
>I like drawing maps and making my own notes

Even though I like all these things, there's one thing that always filters me in these games: the combat. No matter how much I try, it seems that all the DRPGs really on two types of battles: the ones where you mash attack until the enemy is dead without worrying about anything and the ones where you try to mash attack to win but the enemy completely destroys your whole party with just one attack. This second option usually becomes a RNG fest, because while the enemy always has this attack that wipes your party, it can use it on turn 1, turn 10 or never use it, so it all comes down to luck.
So, what you do to enjoy this? Do you just accept that combat is shit and decide to have a good time with the remaining characteristics of the game?

com: I know Todd said that he doesn't want the return of stuff like levitation because verticality makes map design difficult but do you think that he's changed his mind about it? Fallout 4 introduced jetpacks in power armor and it seems that in Starfield jetpacks are going to be a core mechanic in exploration. How vertical do you think ES6 will be? Open world games are judged by their traversal methods and verticality would certainly add new elements in the exploration of TES games. This can be as simple as something like parkour or as esoteric as magical flight fitting for a fantasy games. ES6 can introduce so many fun mobility options for players to choose. A dwemer grappling gun, magic wall climbing, summoning vines with magic, levitation, jumping really high either through spells or just strength, or even flying controllable mounts or mounts that can stick on walls.

>>2880956
Random encounters are not coming back. Even back in their heyday most players cited them as their least favorite aspect of rpgs. Yeah turn-based battles are also a product of the same time period and limitations, but it has become its own battle-style and most DQ fans prefer it.

Using Zoom indoors causing you to bump your head was funny in the 2D games, but it becomes tedious when it takes far longer to exit 3D locations. In 2D you can literally exit most towns from the center in 5 seconds. In 3D you may be on the 4th floor of a building or castle with no balconies and it feels like busywork to treck down several floors just to exit so you can warp. If you had to revisit a long cave to find some treasure you missed or enemies to add to bestiary, it may take 30 secs to exit 2D dungeons but 5 to 10 mins in 3D. This is also the reason for in dungeon healing spots, as in 2D games you were always 20 secs or less, in walking time, away from a town when you left a dungeon.

I don't know why you want to make it harder to level up by requiring more exp or making metal enemies harder to find/kill. Even with the current exp/enemy setup DQ 8 and 11 are still very long games. Those games are the perfect length and don't need to be artificially made twice as long. High exp requirement was just padding usually done as a substitute for actual content.

To me it just sounds like you are the old school type that literally could enjoy grinding out Cloud and Barrets first 6 limit breaks in Mako Reactor 1 area or found the DQ2 Rhone grind to be your favorite part of the game. While there are other people that enjoy that stuff, most would not.

DQ2 demands a lot of grinding and has very difficult enemies. It is almost always listed last in most people's DQ rankings. 7's length is brought up more as a negative than a positive, as is the slow leveling/classing.

>>2882232
>By virtue of having actual functional combat, every single quest in bg has multiple ways it can be solved based on tactical decisions, resource application, and party composition
So it has "shoot at Cyberdemon until it dies" with different weapons? Wow, much roleplay. Different solutions means stealth to avoid, bribes to get past (and not necessarily to the NPCs immediately in front of the party), persuasion or intimidation, using a third faction to remove the obstacle in some manner, or if the obstacle is as simple as a bunch of armed dudes guarding a chokepoint then securing means of magical or technological transportation past them (like repairing or even building an airship). Or maybe manipulating environment so that the leave if they don't like, say, high humidity. Or high/low temperatures. Or maybe you scare them away with something, maybe you learn (not necessarily from dialogues) that they're superstitious. No, the fear spells don't work because you have to kill everything anyway, those are merely debuffs, an aspect of combat.
If your only options are different means of killing things that get in your way it's either an action game or maybe a tactics game. Nothing wrong with either, of course.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: RPGs have a layer of abstraction between the player and the player character(s), in that the player character(s) are for all intents and purposes their own beings with their own abilities, needs, and goals (decided the game's systems and story) and not merely vessels of the player. The more that the player character(s)'(s) skills matter more than the player's, the more the game is a RPG. The less, the less.
